name: Frequently Asked Questions - Erbium Laser Harmony XL Pro

mainEntity.name: What is the Erbium laser and how does it work?

acceptedAnswer.text:
The Erbium laser of the Harmony XL Pro system is an ablative technology that removes superficial skin layers to treat spots, fine wrinkles, and scars.
Its 2940 nm wavelength allows precise ablation with less thermal damage compared to other lasers, favoring faster recovery and effective results in facial rejuvenation.

mainEntity.name: How many sessions are needed to see results?

acceptedAnswer.text:
The number of sessions varies according to the condition to be treated. For spots and rejuvenation, **1 to 3 sessions** are usually recommended, with intervals of 4 to 6 weeks.
First changes can be noticed after the first session, but regeneration and collagen production effects continue improving in subsequent months.

mainEntity.name: How is the recovery after treatment?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Recovery time depends on the intensity of the treatment.
In mild procedures, there is slight redness and peeling for 3 to 5 days. In deeper treatments, recovery can take between 7 and 10 days.
It is fundamental to use sunscreen and avoid direct sun exposure.

The procedure may generate a sensation of heat or burning, but topical anesthesia is applied for greater comfort.
After the session, the skin may be red and with slight inflammation, similar to a mild sunburn, which disappears in a few days.

mainEntity.name: Can the Erbium laser be used on dark skin?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Yes, but with caution.
Unlike other ablative lasers, Erbium has a lower risk of hyperpigmentation in dark skins.
However, in cases of phototypes IV-VI, a prior medical evaluation and a personalized protocol are recommended to avoid side effects.

mainEntity.name: How long do Erbium laser results last?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Results can last between **1 and 3 years**, depending on skin type, aftercare, and sun exposure.
To maintain effects, an annual maintenance session together with a proper skincare routine is recommended.
